article.title: Upper Limits to Magnetic Fields in the Outskirts of Galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the red ellipses in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The area covered by the IRAM telescope beam.
Regions used to measure the CO(2-1) luminosities.
The location of the galactic nuclei.
Areas where CO(2-1) line emission is not detected.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the absence of a peak in the blue spectrum for NGC 2841 indicate?
choices: No CO(2-1) line emission was detected at the galaxy nucleus.
The telescope was not pointed at the correct coordinates.
The galaxy is too far away for CO(2-1) emission to be detected.
The gas density in this galaxy is too low to produce detectable emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical property does Equation (1) primarily aim to constrain?
What can be inferred from the values of Tkin for the outskirts and nuclei in Table 4?
choices: Molecular gas is significantly hotter in the nuclei of galaxies.
Molecular gas temperature remains relatively constant between outskirts and nuclei.
CO column density is a better indicator of temperature variations within a galaxy.
LVG modeling is unreliable for estimating temperatures in galaxy outskirts.
